title: Review of Susan Wollenberg, Schubert’s Fingerprints: Studies in the Instrumental Works (Ashgate, 2011)

FN1.text: 1. Wollenberg 1998 and 2007 . Despite the same title of the latter essay and Chapter 3, the contents of the two studies are different.

FN2.text: 2. These types and brief examples are laid out in Wollenberg 1998 , 16–27.

FN3.text: 3. I shall consider Chapters 5 and 6 shortly. Although I hint above that some of the chapters in the book could have been placed in a different order, the fact is that many of the fingerprints are so intertwined that many different orderings are possible. It seems that Wollenberg has gone for a design where the fingerprints are chiefly discussed in the order in which they are most likely to appear in a musical form, starting with the major–minor mixture at the beginning of works (Chapter 1) to the heavenly length of Schubert’s finales (Chapter 9).

FN4.text: 4. Wollenberg explains (9) that her bibliography contains items consulted, but not directly cited. A number of “new musicology” and music theoretical texts fall into this category.
